Hiya Jill. 
=C2=A0
Most likely most are busy with work, kids going back to =
school, and family from the holidays. No you arent the only one who gets th=
ose types of messages. As for the name thing some do give names and some do=
n't. I have been given full names of those who passed or those who I will l=
ater meet many of which I never heard of until then. I dont think names are=
 quite as important once the physical body it was labeled upon passes on. S=
ome have stated they do not have names or never have been born as we were.
=
=C2=A0
As for why you dont get the reply you wish for or the magic words...=
. take a look around. This board is a good example of how you dont always g=
et the reponse you wish for or the answers to all of your questions hehehe.=

=C2=A0
Hope you had a great holiday and good luck in the upcoming year!
=
=C2=A0
Misty

--- On Mon, 1/4/10, Jill <jjkamp@...> wrote:


From: =
Jill <jjkamp@...>
Subject: [EVP-ITC] Re: Types of messages
To: EVP-=
ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Monday, January 4, 2010, 10:37 PM


=C2=A0 



So=
 I'm guessing no one else here gets "I love you" from the entities? It's ju=
st me? (I'm just that loveable?) 

--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com, "Jill" =
<jjkamp@...> wrote:
>
> On New Year's Eve and New Year's Day I did two sess=
ions with two different sets of participants. The messages always seem to b=
e the same, though: "I love you." Over and over, threading all through the =
recording, both in the background, and more overtly when I ask a specific q=
uestion such as, "Do you have a message for Heather?" Does anyone else get =
this? I mean, it's flattering and all, but it doesn't really mean that much=
 when I don't know for sure who's telling me this.
> 
> Also, "they" seem q=
uite ready to tell me their first names, but almost never their last names.=
 Why? Do last names cease to exist on the other side? Or is there some unwr=
itten rule that says verifiable information can't be passed along? If so, w=
ho makes and enforces these rules?
> 
> And if they can so easily say a nam=
e four times in a row (yesterday it was my friend's grandfather' s name Don=
ald), why can't they say one word to me that would mean something? Or to my=
 friend Heather? We both asked, and got nothing, at least not that we could=
 discern. It would seem a simple thing to say the word plumber (that was my=
 dad's secret word) or some other single-syllable word. Now I'm pretty sure=
 I really did talk to my dad, as I had another "contact" from him in my wak=
ing dream state the other morning, but if it's really him, why can't he say=
 something he would've said in life? Why do I have the nagging feeling that=
 "they" aren't human and never were? 
> 
> I just don't get it! Any thought=
s, guys?
>
